lines.text: Enter DUKE, THURIO, and PROTEUS

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Sir Thurio, give us leave, I pray, awhile We have some secrets to confer about. Now, tell me, Proteus, whats your will with me
Exit THURIO

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: My gracious lord, that which I would discover The law of friendship bids me to conceal But when I call to mind your gracious favours Done to me, undeserving as I am, My duty pricks me on to utter that Which else no worldly good should draw from me. Know, worthy prince, Sir Valentine, my friend, This night intends to steal away your daughter: Myself am one made privy to the plot. I know you have determined to bestow her On Thurio, whom your gentle daughter hates And should she thus be stoln away from you, It would be much vexation to your age. Thus, for my dutys sake, I rather chose To cross my friend in his intended drift Than, by concealing it, heap on your head A pack of sorrows which would press you down, Being unprevented, to your timeless grave.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Proteus, I thank thee for thine honest care Which to requite, command me while I live. This love of theirs myself have often seen, Haply when they have judged me fast asleep, And oftentimes have purposed to forbid Sir Valentine her company and my court: But fearing lest my jealous aim might err And so unworthily disgrace the man, A rashness that I ever yet have shunnd, I gave him gentle looks, thereby to find That which thyself hast now disclosed to me. And, that thou mayst perceive my fear of this, Knowing that tender youth is soon suggested, I nightly lodge her in an upper tower, The key whereof myself have ever kept And thence she cannot be conveyd away.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Know, noble lord, they have devised a mean How he her chamberwindow will ascend And with a corded ladder fetch her down For which the youthful lover now is gone And this way comes he with it presently Where, if it please you, you may intercept him. But, good my Lord, do it so cunningly That my discovery be not aimed at For love of you, not hate unto my friend, Hath made me publisher of this pretence.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Upon mine honour, he shall never know That I had any light from thee of this.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Adieu, my Lord Sir Valentine is coming.
Exit
Enter VALENTINE

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Sir Valentine, whither away so fast

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Please it your grace, there is a messenger That stays to bear my letters to my friends, And I am going to deliver them.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Be they of much import

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: The tenor of them doth but signify My health and happy being at your court.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Nay then, no matter stay with me awhile I am to break with thee of some affairs That touch me near, wherein thou must be secret. Tis not unknown to thee that I have sought To match my friend Sir Thurio to my daughter.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: I know it well, my Lord and, sure, the match Were rich and honourable besides, the gentleman Is full of virtue, bounty, worth and qualities Beseeming such a wife as your fair daughter: Cannot your Grace win her to fancy him

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: No, trust me she is peevish, sullen, froward, Proud, disobedient, stubborn, lacking duty, Neither regarding that she is my child Nor fearing me as if I were her father And, may I say to thee, this pride of hers, Upon advice, hath drawn my love from her And, where I thought the remnant of mine age Should have been cherishd by her childlike duty, I now am full resolved to take a wife And turn her out to who will take her in: Then let her beauty be her weddingdower For me and my possessions she esteems not.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: What would your Grace have me to do in this

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: There is a lady in Verona here Whom I affect but she is nice and coy And nought esteems my aged eloquence: Now therefore would I have thee to my tutor For long agone I have forgot to court Besides, the fashion of the time is changed How and which way I may bestow myself To be regarded in her sunbright eye.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Win her with gifts, if she respect not words: Dumb jewels often in their silent kind More than quick words do move a womans mind.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: But she did scorn a present that I sent her.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: A woman sometimes scorns what best contents her. Send her another never give her oer For scorn at first makes afterlove the more. If she do frown, tis not in hate of you, But rather to beget more love in you: If she do chide, tis not to have you gone For why, the fools are mad, if left alone. Take no repulse, whatever she doth say For get you gone, she doth not mean away! Flatter and praise, commend, extol their graces Though neer so black, say they have angels faces. That man that hath a tongue, I say, is no man, If with his tongue he cannot win a woman.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: But she I mean is promised by her friends Unto a youthful gentleman of worth, And kept severely from resort of men, That no man hath access by day to her.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Why, then, I would resort to her by night.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Ay, but the doors be lockd and keys kept safe, That no man hath recourse to her by night.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: What lets but one may enter at her window

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground, And built so shelving that one cannot climb it Without apparent hazard of his life.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Why then, a ladder quaintly made of cords, To cast up, with a pair of anchoring hooks, Would serve to scale another Heros tower, So bold Leander would adventure it.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Now, as thou art a gentleman of blood, Advise me where I may have such a ladder.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: When would you use it pray, sir, tell me that.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: This very night for Love is like a child, That longs for every thing that he can come by.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: By seven oclock Ill get you such a ladder.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: But, hark thee I will go to her alone: How shall I best convey the ladder thither

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: It will be light, my lord, that you may bear it Under a cloak that is of any length.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: A cloak as long as thine will serve the turn

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Ay, my good lord.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Then let me see thy cloak: Ill get me one of such another length.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Why, any cloak will serve the turn, my lord.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: How shall I fashion me to wear a cloak I pray thee, let me feel thy cloak upon me. What letter is this same Whats here To Silvia! And here an engine fit for my proceeding. Ill be so bold to break the seal for once. My thoughts do harbour with my Silvia nightly, And slaves they are to me that send them flying: O, could their master come and go as lightly, Himself would lodge where senseless they are lying! My herald thoughts in thy pure bosom rest them: While I, their king, that hither them importune, Do curse the grace that with such grace hath blessd them, Because myself do want my servants fortune: I curse myself, for they are sent by me, That they should harbour where their lord would be. Whats here Silvia, this night I will enfranchise thee. Tis so and heres the ladder for the purpose. Why, Phaeton,for thou art Merops son, Wilt thou aspire to guide the heavenly car And with thy daring folly burn the world Wilt thou reach stars, because they shine on thee Go, base intruder! overweening slave! Bestow thy fawning smiles on equal mates, And think my patience, more than thy desert, Is privilege for thy departure hence: Thank me for this more than for all the favours Which all too much I have bestowd on thee. But if thou linger in my territories Longer than swiftest expedition Will give thee time to leave our royal court, By heaven! my wrath shall far exceed the love I ever bore my daughter or thyself. Be gone! I will not hear thy vain excuse But, as thou lovest thy life, make speed from hence.
Reads
Exit

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: And why not death rather than living torment To die is to be banishd from myself And Silvia is myself: banishd from her Is self from self: a deadly banishment! What light is light, if Silvia be not seen What joy is joy, if Silvia be not by Unless it be to think that she is by And feed upon the shadow of perfection Except I be by Silvia in the night, There is no music in the nightingale Unless I look on Silvia in the day, There is no day for me to look upon She is my essence, and I leave to be, If I be not by her fair influence Fosterd, illumined, cherishd, kept alive. I fly not death, to fly his deadly doom: Tarry I here, I but attend on death: But, fly I hence, I fly away from life.
Enter PROTEUS and LAUNCE

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Run, boy, run, run, and seek him out.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Soho, soho!

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: What seest thou

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Him we go to find: theres not a hair ons head but tis a Valentine.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Valentine

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Who then his spirit

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Neither.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: What then

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Nothing.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Can nothing speak Master, shall I strike

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Who wouldst thou strike

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Nothing.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Villain, forbear.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Why, sir, Ill strike nothing: I pray you,

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Sirrah, I say, forbear. Friend Valentine, a word.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: My ears are stopt and cannot hear good news, So much of bad already hath possessd them.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Then in dumb silence will I bury mine, For they are harsh, untuneable and bad.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Is Silvia dead

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: No, Valentine.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: No Valentine, indeed, for sacred Silvia. Hath she forsworn me

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: No, Valentine.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: No Valentine, if Silvia have forsworn me. What is your news

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Sir, there is a proclamation that you are vanished.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: That thou art banishedO, thats the news! From hence, from Silvia and from me thy friend.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: O, I have fed upon this woe already, And now excess of it will make me surfeit. Doth Silvia know that I am banished

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Ay, ay and she hath offerd to the doom Which, unreversed, stands in effectual force A sea of melting pearl, which some call tears: Those at her fathers churlish feet she tenderd With them, upon her knees, her humble self Wringing her hands, whose whiteness so became them As if but now they waxed pale for woe: But neither bended knees, pure hands held up, Sad sighs, deep groans, nor silvershedding tears, Could penetrate her uncompassionate sire But Valentine, if he be taen, must die. Besides, her intercession chafed him so, When she for thy repeal was suppliant, That to close prison he commanded her, With many bitter threats of biding there.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: No more unless the next word that thou speakst Have some malignant power upon my life: If so, I pray thee, breathe it in mine ear, As ending anthem of my endless dolour.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Cease to lament for that thou canst not help, And study help for that which thou lamentst. Time is the nurse and breeder of all good. Here if thou stay, thou canst not see thy love Besides, thy staying will abridge thy life. Hope is a lovers staff walk hence with that And manage it against despairing thoughts. Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence Which, being writ to me, shall be deliverd Even in the milkwhite bosom of thy love. The time now serves not to expostulate: Come, Ill convey thee through the citygate And, ere I part with thee, confer at large Of all that may concern thy loveaffairs. As thou lovest Silvia, though not for thyself, Regard thy danger, and along with me!

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: I pray thee, Launce, an if thou seest my boy, Bid him make haste and meet me at the Northgate.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Go, sirrah, find him out. Come, Valentine.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: O my dear Silvia! Hapless Valentine!
Exeunt VALENTINE and PROTEUS

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: I am but a fool, look you and yet I have the wit to think my master is a kind of a knave: but thats all one, if he be but one knave. He lives not now that knows me to be in love yet I am in love but a team of horse shall not pluck that from me nor who tis I love and yet tis a woman but what woman, I will not tell myself and yet tis a milkmaid yet tis not a maid, for she hath had gossips yet tis a maid, for she is her masters maid, and serves for wages. She hath more qualities than a waterspaniel which is much in a bare Christian. Here is the catelog of her condition. Imprimis: She can fetch and carry. Why, a horse can do no more: nay, a horse cannot fetch, but only carry therefore is she better than a jade. Item: She can milk look you, a sweet virtue in a maid with clean hands.
Pulling out a paper
Enter SPEED

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: How now, Signior Launce! what news with your mastership

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: With my masters ship why, it is at sea.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Well, your old vice still mistake the word. What news, then, in your paper

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: The blackest news that ever thou heardest.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Why, man, how black

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Why, as black as ink.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Let me read them.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Fie on thee, jolthead! thou canst not read.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Thou liest I can.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: I will try thee. Tell me this: who begot thee

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Marry, the son of my grandfather.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: O illiterate loiterer! it was the son of thy grandmother: this proves that thou canst not read.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Come, fool, come try me in thy paper.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: There and St. Nicholas be thy speed!

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: [Reads]  Imprimis: She can milk.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Ay, that she can.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She brews good ale.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: And thereof comes the proverb: Blessing of your heart, you brew good ale.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She can sew.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Thats as much as to say, Can she so

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She can knit.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: What need a man care for a stock with a wench, when she can knit him a stock

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She can wash and scour.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: A special virtue: for then she need not be washed and scoured.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She can spin.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Then may I set the world on wheels, when she can spin for her living.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She hath many nameless virtues.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Thats as much as to say, bastard virtues that, indeed, know not their fathers and therefore have no names.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Here follow her vices.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Close at the heels of her virtues.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She is not to be kissed fasting in respect of her breath.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Well, that fault may be mended with a breakfast. Read on.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She hath a sweet mouth.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: That makes amends for her sour breath.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She doth talk in her sleep.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Its no matter for that, so she sleep not in her talk.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She is slow in words.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: O villain, that set this down among her vices! To be slow in words is a womans only virtue: I pray thee, out witht, and place it for her chief virtue.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She is proud.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Out with that too it was Eves legacy, and cannot be taen from her.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She hath no teeth.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: I care not for that neither, because I love crusts.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She is curst.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Well, the best is, she hath no teeth to bite.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She will often praise her liquor.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: If her liquor be good, she shall: if she will not, I will for good things should be praised.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She is too liberal.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Of her tongue she cannot, for thats writ down she is slow of of her purse she shall not, for that Ill keep shut: now, of another thing she may, and that cannot I help. Well, proceed.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She hath more hair than wit, and more faults than hairs, and more wealth than faults.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Stop there Ill have her: she was mine, and not mine, twice or thrice in that last article. Rehearse that once more.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Item: She hath more hair than wit,

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: More hair than wit It may be Ill prove it. The cover of the salt hides the salt, and therefore it is more than the salt the hair that covers the wit is more than the wit, for the greater hides the less. Whats next

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: And more faults than hairs,

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Thats monstrous: O, that that were out!

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: And more wealth than faults.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Why, that word makes the faults gracious. Well, Ill have her and if it be a match, as nothing is impossible,

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: What then

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Why, then will I tell theethat thy master stays for thee at the Northgate.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: For me

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: For thee! ay, who art thou he hath stayed for a better man than thee.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: And must I go to him

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Thou must run to him, for thou hast stayed so long that going will scarce serve the turn.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Why didst not tell me sooner pox of your love letters!
Exit

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Now will he be swinged for reading my letter an unmannerly slave, that will thrust himself into secrets! Ill after, to rejoice in the boys correction.
Exit
